reading.text: According to experts, nearly 25% of Britons, including children, are overweight. The government is worried and it is looking for ways to solve the problem.

In the UK, 1 in 4 year olds already co cookery at school but from 2011, the government is making this compulsory. They hope that this will encourage people to cook instead of eating ready meals, fast food and snacks.

At secondary school students will have cooking lessons for one hour a week. Eventually they will learn to use simple, fresh ingredients and simple recipes to prepare healthy, tasty meals, for example a good tomato and pasta dish.
And schools are setting up cookery clubs called 'Let's Get Cooking' throughout the country. The clubs give children and parents the chance to learn to cook after school.
Head Teachers worry about the equipment they will need for the lessons. About 10% of schools do not have kitchens and there are not enough cookery facilities.
The government is promising to train 800 cookery teachers and to give schools £2.5 million a year to help children from poorer families to pay for ingredients.

grammar.title: do, have or make - Verb Collocations
grammar.explanation: Some verbs are commonly used with specific nouns. These combinations are called collocations. In English, we use 'do', 'have', and 'make' in different situations.

affirmative: My sister and I never do/have/make any arguments.
My father always does/has/makes our holiday arrangements.
My brother is so lazy! He never does/has/makes any homework at all.
I'm worried about Lukas – he is doing/having/making badly at school right now.
negative: You can use the kitchen – but please don't do/have/make a mess!
I don't have to can should mustn't speak English perfectly but they must can usually be able to explain things clearly.
questions: You have to do/have/make your homework before you go out.
My mum says I should do/have/make my bed before going to school.
In Spain, people often do/have/make dinner at 9 p.m.

quiz.question: Choose the words a–c that can complete the phrase: 1. a healthy ___
quiz.explanation: Both 'a healthy diet' and 'a healthy lifestyle' are correct collocations.

quiz.question: 2. to ___ weight
quiz.explanation: Both 'put on weight' and 'lose weight' are correct.

quiz.question: 3. a bowl of ___
quiz.explanation: 'A bowl of cereal' and 'a bowl of soup' are both correct.

quiz.question: 4. a ___ lunch
quiz.explanation: 'A school lunch' and 'a packed lunch' are both correct.

quiz.question: 5. a can of ___
quiz.explanation: 'A can of lemonade' and 'a can of cola' are both correct.

quiz.question: 6. to commit ___
quiz.explanation: 'Commit a murder' and 'commit a crime' are correct collocations.
